content.description: The crux of the climb is definitely the bottom portion. It takes a while to learn the correct beta for pulling up under the roof without swinging off. Pulling up over the roof is pretty easy once you get there. There are a lot of good holds to choose from. The only tricky thing about the roof is there are no feet once you have it. Heel hooks work well and help move the hands up. The rest of the climb is fairy simple.
content.protection: Use a crash pad at the roof and there are two top anchors.
content.location: Go left from the main area till you hit a large roof. The climb starts directly underneath the roof. Right of Slacker

content.description: The start is pretty reachy, but has good ledges to hold. Once you get to the wave like feature, the holds become rare. There are two side pulls and a few little pockets. The next hold is the top ledge that is out of reach. The crack to the left and protruding rock is off for the climb because it is a part of another route. You might have to resort to dynamic moves in order to get the ledge.
content.location: Same wall as Small Wave, but a little to the left. Next the giant overhang.

content.description: Small Wave has a really interesting feature where the rock curves out at you little. This feature makes for some unique moves on the wall. There are good ledges spread out every now and then making the route doable by all dynos. I suggest you try to completely dyno the route if you can do it static.
content.location: Farther to left from Jeff's Corner. There is a huge overhang just to the left of the wall.

content.description: The top of Slacker is fairly easy with many good holds; however, the bottom part is where the difficulty comes in. There are very few small crimps and pinches underneath to use. Foot placement is key for getting over the overhang. I found a heel hook works best.
content.protection: Two top anchors and crash pad (if you fall off roof).
content.location: Left of Small Wave where the giant overhang is.

content.description: The crux is finding the little crimps in order to reach the ledges. After you find them, the climb becomes much easier. The top ledge that looks good from the ground is actually a little slopey, so watch out for that. This route can be a high ball problem, but topping out is dangerous.
content.protection: Use two trees and a static rope for an anchor.
content.location: On the left side of Middle Wall. Left of Big Ball.

content.description: Start on the corner of the rock and work your way straight up. It can get tricky at the top because the feet disappear and the holds are out of reach. The hand holds are good to just cut feet and hang on.
content.location: This route is on the corner of the large overhang next to Small Wave.

content.description: The start is pretty easy to make it up, it's the same as "Right Crack". The traverse over to the left crack is kind of tricky to keep your balance. The top part is a little bit reachy to top-out.
content.location: On the corner of the big overhang, left of "Right Crack"

content.description: Start on the ledge and work your way up and into the giant off-width. There are multiple ways to get out of this, using the ledge at the top left is one of the easiest ways. There is a flake and a jug high and above the left hand ledge, then reaching the top shouldn't be difficult.
content.protection: Use a static rope with two trees
content.location: Inbetween is located on the right corner of Middle Wall, it's to the right of Small Wave.

content.description: The bottom portion of the route is straightforward. There are a few ledges that need to be used, then a few small pockets, back up to some ledges. The very top is very difficult with only a small, slopey crimp to help reach the top. The arete is hard to use because it is very mossy and dirty.
content.protection: Use two trees and a static rope.
content.location: Happy Tree Friend is located on the right side of Middle Wall, next to a tree that hugs the wall.

content.description: Getting over the hump is the crux of the climb. It involves a lot of body tension and small crimps. The top portion of the climb is fairly simple with lots of jugs and ledges.
content.protection: Use a static rope with two trees
content.location: This climb is on the corner of Middle Wall, to the right of Inbetween.

content.description: The beginning has two crimps fairly high up. From there, make your way up to the big ball like hold. Reach up high and then finish the route. This could be a high ball problem for some people that like bouldering; however, topping out would be hard.
content.protection: Use two trees and a static rope to setup an anchor.
content.location: On the left arete of Middle Wall. Located on the very left of the big roof.

content.description: Back Breaker starts as a small overhang where the climber starts underneath the rock. The right hand starts on a really good side pull while the left hand starts on a crimp. Find a really good heel hook next to the left hand and work your way to the top. You will probably need to play around with different hand holds near the beginning, but the end is easy. The picture provides where the start holds are.
content.protection: I would use a pretty big pad or two small pads. The only dangerous part is the rock directly below the climb. Could easily fall on the rock and hurt your back.
content.location: Back Breaker is a small nose like feature way left on Middle Wall that leads to the path behind Middle Wall. Just follow the wall till you hit this boulder problem.

content.description: Middle Wall has climbs that have a little bit higher grading than the other areas. The climbs here can be challenging, but are very unique with different movements that aren't generally used at Area 31 such as heel hooks and unique with the interesting rock formations. When doing climbs under the roof, a crash pad may be necessary in case you fall and hit the ground. The three sets of bolts are located on top by the large overhanging boulder. If you're looking for more challenging climbs, this would be the area to focus on.
